column2: 1. When you're coding, how often do you have R open somewhere on your computer (in any form, including RStudio desktop, RStudio server, or Microsoft R Open)? Note: If â€œnever,â€ please feel free to skip the remaining questions.
column3: 2. When you're coding, how often are you listening to music? Note: If â€œnever,â€ please feel free to skip the remaining questions. Though also feel free to read out of curiosity and answer when it makes sense.
column4: 3. Do you enjoy hearing music that's new to you... including while you code? Note: If â€œactively dislike,â€ please feel free to skip the remaining questions. Though also feel free to read out of curiosity and answer when it makes sense.
column5: 4. How often do you share the music you're listening to with other people?
column6: 5â€“8. Of the time you're coding to music, how often do you listen toâ€¦ [a set playlist]
column7: 5â€“8. Of the time you're coding to music, how often do you listen toâ€¦ [a radio-like experience]
column8: 5â€“8. Of the time you're coding to music, how often do you listen toâ€¦ [a song on repeat]
column9: 5â€“8. Of the time you're coding to music, how often do you listen toâ€¦ [random songs]
column10: 9. Only if you're comfortable answering: When you have R open, how often is it running on a remote machine, e.g. on RStudio Server or via SSH?
column11: 1. A real-time collaborative playlist / radio experience? You & others would listen to the same music at the same time, and any of you can add music for the group as you go.
column12: 2. Interacting with the playlist using R (connected to a server via plumber API)? For example, there might be functions to list and join active stations, add tracks, upvote / downvote songs, flag content, and save music for later.
column13: 3. Connecting your listening experience to Twitter? I.e. you might know that you're collaborating with @thomasp85 on a station inspired by Koop, or you could invite @beeonaposy to listen to Ratatat.
column14: 4. Creating and editing playlists within the same experience? For example, sometimes you might just listen to a playlistâ€”but this feature would also help you organize tracks for easy recall later.
column15: 5. All your data being available to you, in a tidy format, to remember just what you listened to on what stations and when?
column16: 6. Sharing some of that data? You would have control over what listening history / upvoting / downvoting / flagging data is publicly visible.
column17: 7. Being able to save your active R project name and filename as secure, one-way hashes? That way you could ask â€œwhat songs did I listen to when I was working on this code?â€ But you couldn't ask â€œwhat projects and files did I code to this song?â€ (And more importantly, no one else could.)
column18: 8. As a data scientist, being able to create & deploy your own music-selecting bots to add tracks to a shared station? You could use R (tutorials + vignettes TBD), with whatever data you and other R users make available as you listen to music.
column19: 9. As a member of the #rstats community, being able to check out the results of other people's music bots?
column20: 10. A shiny web app to open this functionality to non-R-users? That way it's not cloistered within the #rstats community. It would still be R-native, though, and (to borrow a phrase from @tylermorganwall) data would be a first-class citizen.
column21: 1. How would you prioritize... the ability to import your current playlists from other services and websites?
column22: 2. How would you prioritize... the ability to sync playlists / favorites back to other services or websites?
column23: 3. If you're comfortable answering, what's streaming service(s) do you usually use to listen to music (e.g. Spotify, Amazon, Apple, Google, YouTube, SoundCloud, or just owned music)?
column24: 4. Among the services you use: Some people have a strong preference for 1â€“2 music servicesâ€”maybe they have a long history with it or they pay for a subscriptionâ€”while others bounce around and listen to music wherever they find it. Where would you place yourself in that spectrum?
column25: 5. If you have a strong preference, do you mind sharing it? If you don't mind, please share below:
column26: 6. How would you want the project to handle it the situation described?
column27: 7. How would you prioritize your preferred solution? (Doesn't apply to all answers.)
column28: 8. Any other comments on music service integration?
column29: 1. Several companies offer authentication services, where you â€œSign in with [company name]â€ (often called OAuth2). If I picked, say, 1â€“2 that most people are OK with, it would streamline the process quite a bit. Which of the following authentication options might you use if it was available? (Select one or more that apply.)
column30: 2. Are there any of these services you would *not* use for authentication? I wouldn't want to prioritize an option that most people are actively opposed to.
column31: 3. Please share anything else youâ€™d like to on authentication. This is important to me, as it could be a barrier to adoption, and it could also be simple to address.
column32: 1. If in the end this appears to be a good ideaâ€”good enough to continueâ€”would you be interested in helping out in any of these ways? If so, please reach out via Twitter (@BenjaminWolfe) or R4DS.online (DM Benjamin Wolfe), or share your contact information in the comments (Twitter or R4DS Slack preferred).
column33: 2. Anything else you'd like to say or ask after reading through the survey? If asking a question, please make sure I know who you are so I can answer you. (Again, Twitter or R4DS Slack handle is preferred, for the sake of manageability.)

column25: I pay for Spotify Premium because it has most of the music I listen to (and keeps updating w. more), and it syncs with my macbook/iphone/google home based on where I started playing music. The second part is especially cool because it creates a seamless experience when switching devices. I'm not sure of other services that do something like that.
column28:
I wanted to quickly say bots might be cool but it might cause a lot of noise. I had the same concern for integration with Twitter; folks might not like seeing flurry of tweets on who's listening to what? (in fact dunno if I've seen this on Twitter). 

I think the ability to programmatically create / edit / share? playlists is a great idea! It's something I had wanted to do but never found the time. The question will be how easy that process is compared to manual playlist creation/sharing that services already provide. Still a very worthwhile project!

column13: I wouldn't post about streams on Twitter. If I feel like posting a record I take a photo of the artwork.
column23:
I  feel I am the wrong person to answer this questionnaire, which is a shame because I am a coding music nerd who spends hundreds of euros on records each month...  :D

I check out bands on YouTube, or, if not available, on Bandcamp (grudgingly because of the poor stream quality). If I like it I buy a record or CD. I dislike the idea of paying for streams or downloads because 1) the artists in most cases basically don't see any of the money and 2) I don't get a product I can hold in my hands.
column25: First press vinyl records. I will never pay for music streaming services.
